t: Oh, That My People Would Listen to Me
To the choirmaster: according to The Gittith. Of Asaph.
Sing*pn aloud to God our strength; shout*ld for joy to the God of Jacob!
Raise*ln a song; sound the tambourine, the*ld sweet lyre with the harp.
Blow*ln the trumpet at the new moon, at*ld the full moon, on our feast day.
For*pn it is a statute for Israel, a*ld rule of the God of Jacob.
He*ln made it a decree in Joseph when*ld he went out over the land of Egypt. I*ln hear a language I had not known:
“I*ln relieved your shoulder of the burden; your*ld hands were freed from the basket.
In*ln distress you called, and I delivered you; I*ld answered you in the secret place of thunder; I*ld tested you at the waters of Meribah. Selah*ig
Hear,*ln O my people, while I admonish you! O*ld Israel, if you would but listen to me!
There*ln shall be no strange god among you; you*ld shall not bow down to a foreign god.
I*ln am the Lord*s your God, who*ld brought you up out of the land of Egypt. Open*ld your mouth wide, and I will fill it.
“But*pn my people did not listen to my voice; Israel*ld would not submit to me.
So*ln I gave them over to their stubborn hearts, to*ld follow their own counsels.
Oh,*ln that my people would listen to me, that*ld Israel would walk in my ways!
I*ln would soon subdue their enemies and*ld turn my hand against their foes.
Those*ln who hate the Lord*s would cringe toward him, and*ld their fate would last forever.
But*ln he would feed you with the finest of the wheat, and*ld with honey from the rock I would satisfy you.”
